message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postoperative pericarditis, with symptoms including stabbing chest pain that is worse with inspiration, diaphoresis, and general distress. Aspirin is the treatment of choice for postoperative pericarditis. Atorvastatin and lisinopril may be used for prevention of future events, but not for acute treatment. Surgery is not indicated for postoperative pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The onset of chest pain with inspiration, diaphoresis, and general distress after post-operative catheterization with ST-elevations on EKG suggests acute pericarditis. Aspirin is the recommended treatment for acute pericarditis. Atorvastatin is a statin used to lower cholesterol levels and is not indicated in the treatment of acute pericarditis. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure but is not indicated in the treatment of acute pericarditis. Surgery is not indicated in the management of acute pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and EKG changes suggest acute pericarditis. Aspirin is the initial treatment of choice for acute pericarditis. Atorvastatin and Lisinopril are not indicated for acute pericarditis. Surgery is not indicated unless there is a complication such as cardiac tamponade.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and EKG suggest postoperative pericarditis. Aspirin is the best treatment for this condition as it has anti-inflammatory properties and helps relieve chest pain. Atorvastatin and Lisinopril are used for different cardiac issues and surgery is not necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pericarditis, which can occur as a complication of cardiac surgery. Aspirin is the preferred treatment for pain relief and anti-inflammatory effects. Atorvastatin is used for cholesterol control and prevention of future cardiovascular events. Lisinopril is used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Surgery is not indicated for pericarditis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest acute pericarditis, which can be treated with aspirin. Atorvastatin is used for high cholesterol, and lisinopril is used for hypertension and heart failure. Surgery may be an option in cases of recurrent pericarditis or complications, but is not the first-line treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient likely developed post-pericardiotomy syndrome, which can occur after cardiac surgery and manifest as chest pain, fever, and diffuse ST-elevations on EKG. Treatment should start with aspirin to reduce inflammation and pain. Atorvastatin and Lisinopril may be used for long-term management of cardiovascular disease but they do not address the acute symptoms. Surgery is not indicated for post-pericardiotomy syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute pericarditis, which can be caused by post-procedure inflammation or viral infection. Aspirin is the first-line treatment for acute pericarditis, whereas the other options are not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has likely developed pericarditis after the catheterization, and the symptoms match with the diagnosis. Aspirin is the mainstay treatment for pericarditis to reduce inflammation and pain. Atorvastatin and lisinopril may be given to prevent further cardiovascular events, but they are not the first-line treatment for pericarditis. Surgery is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute pericarditis, which can be treated with aspirin. Atorvastatin is used to lower cholesterol levels, lisinopril is used to treat hypertension and surgery is not indicated for acute pericarditis.
